title: How to Glue Wood Together

steps.headline: Decide if your project is right for normal white glue.
steps.description: White glue is best for indoor projects that have a low to moderate amount of wear. White glue is also preferred for smaller craft projects rather than furniture. If your wood project will be used regularly or is large, move on to the next method, using yellow carpenter’s glue.

steps.headline: Purchase a white, polyvinyl acetate glue that is not meant for children’s use.
steps.description: Children’s glues are usually watered down for safety.

steps.headline: Apply the white glue to the edge or joint of your piece with a small paintbrush.
steps.description: Be sure to apply it to one side of the entire edge that will be glued.

steps.headline: Affix the joint or wood pieces together on a worktable or craft surface.
steps.description: Placing it near the edge of your table will make it easier to clamp.

steps.headline: Place the wood between two scrap pieces of wood.
steps.description: Cover these scrap pieces in contact paper or tape to keep them from sticking to your wood.

steps.headline: Use screw clamps, C-clamps or spring clamps.
steps.description: Screw clamps are best with larger projects.

steps.headline: Screw the clamps into place and allow excess glue to press out of the areas where the wood pieces meet.
steps.description: Resist the temptation to wipe it up with a wet cloth, since it can dilute the glue. Instead wipe it with a dry cloth or sand it off later.

steps.headline: Clamp for at least two hours, but give most projects overnight to cure.
Choose yellow carpenter’s glue for indoor furniture projects.
steps.description: This is usually made of aliphatic resins and sold in squeeze bottles.

steps.headline: Set your pieces of wood atop a worktable or surface.
steps.description: Make sure it is covered with something that is a little slippery so the wood doesn’t get stuck to your table.

steps.headline: Apply a bead of glue to one side of the joint that will be glued together.
steps.description: Then, brush it to the edges with a paintbrush.

steps.headline: Place the wood pieces together firmly.
steps.description: Make sure they are aligned.

steps.headline: Start clamping the wood pieces down first.
steps.description: Set cauls, or wood pieces, covered in packing tape on top of the wood pieces. Then, clamp them down with screw clamps. If possible do this on each side.

steps.headline: Clamp the wood pieces toward each other with bar clamps.
steps.description: Alternate putting the clamps below the wood piece and above it to ensure an even adhesion.

steps.headline: Look for evidence that there is the same amount of glue pressing out of the joint at either end.
steps.description: If there isn’t, it means one of your bar clamps is likely tighter than the others.

steps.headline: Wait one hour to remove this bead of glue.
steps.description: Then, remove it with a utility knife blade. When the project is unclamped, it will be easy to sand off.

steps.headline: Keep the pieces clamped for two hours or longer.
steps.description: It sets quickly at warmer temperatures, but can be used at 45 degrees Fahrenheit (7.2 Celsius).

steps.headline: Determine if your project will have contact with water.
steps.description: If so, you will need to use resorcinol formaldehyde glue to ensure adhesion. It can be used on doors, windows and even aquatic equipment. Keep in mind that waterproof wood glue is significantly more expensive that yellow or white glue.

steps.headline: Use a similar method when gluing outdoor and indoor projects together.
steps.description: You will need bar clamps, screw clamps and cauls to ensure good adhesion.

steps.headline: Set up your workstation in a warm area.
steps.description: The glue needs a warm environment to activate.

steps.headline: Mix the glue together just before you glue the wood.
steps.description: Blend the resin and the catalyst according to package directions.

steps.headline: Apply it to the joints and clamp.
steps.description: Then leave it to dry for 10 hours.

steps.headline: Wipe up excess with a dry cloth.
steps.description: It dries a deep maroon color. Sand off the remainder of the glue after it has set.

text: Gluing Craft Projects Together Decide if your project is right for normal white glue. White glue is best for indoor projects that have a low to moderate amount of wear. White glue is also preferred for smaller craft projects rather than furniture. If your wood project will be used regularly or is large, move on to the next method, using yellow carpenter’s glue. Purchase a white, polyvinyl acetate glue that is not meant for children’s use. Children’s glues are usually watered down for safety. Apply the white glue to the edge or joint of your piece with a small paintbrush. Be sure to apply it to one side of the entire edge that will be glued. Affix the joint or wood pieces together on a worktable or craft surface. Placing it near the edge of your table will make it easier to clamp. Place the wood between two scrap pieces of wood. Cover these scrap pieces in contact paper or tape to keep them from sticking to your wood. Use screw clamps, C-clamps or spring clamps. Screw clamps are best with larger projects. Screw the clamps into place and allow excess glue to press out of the areas where the wood pieces meet. Resist the temptation to wipe it up with a wet cloth, since it can dilute the glue. Instead wipe it with a dry cloth or sand it off later. Clamp for at least two hours, but give most projects overnight to cure.  Gluing Furniture\/Indoor Projects Together Choose yellow carpenter’s glue for indoor furniture projects. This is usually made of aliphatic resins and sold in squeeze bottles. Set your pieces of wood atop a worktable or surface. Make sure it is covered with something that is a little slippery so the wood doesn’t get stuck to your table. Apply a bead of glue to one side of the joint that will be glued together. Then, brush it to the edges with a paintbrush. Place the wood pieces together firmly. Make sure they are aligned. Start clamping the wood pieces down first. Set cauls, or wood pieces, covered in packing tape on top of the wood pieces. Then, clamp them down with screw clamps. If possible do this on each side. Clamp the wood pieces toward each other with bar clamps. Alternate putting the clamps below the wood piece and above it to ensure an even adhesion. Look for evidence that there is the same amount of glue pressing out of the joint at either end. If there isn’t, it means one of your bar clamps is likely tighter than the others. Wait one hour to remove this bead of glue. Then, remove it with a utility knife blade. When the project is unclamped, it will be easy to sand off. Keep the pieces clamped for two hours or longer. It sets quickly at warmer temperatures, but can be used at 45 degrees Fahrenheit (7.2 Celsius). Gluing Outdoor Glue Together Determine if your project will have contact with water. If so, you will need to use resorcinol formaldehyde glue to ensure adhesion. It can be used on doors, windows and even aquatic equipment. Keep in mind that waterproof wood glue is significantly more expensive that yellow or white glue. Use a similar method when gluing outdoor and indoor projects together. You will need bar clamps, screw clamps and cauls to ensure good adhesion. Set up your workstation in a warm area. The glue needs a warm environment to activate. Mix the glue together just before you glue the wood. Blend the resin and the catalyst according to package directions. Apply it to the joints and clamp. Then leave it to dry for 10 hours. Wipe up excess with a dry cloth. It dries a deep maroon color. Sand off the remainder of the glue after it has set.
